comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: A January 27, 1918 New York Times article refers to Yussif Hussane as "a Balkan" heavyweight wrestler. He was fighting Joe Stecher. I found a reference to an earlier fight between Hussane and Stecher on November 25, 1915, at Lincoln, Nebraska (on this web page). Another bout pairing the long-time rivals took place in Atlanta in 1923. He also fought Stanislaus Zbyszko at least once, in July, 1924, at the Los Angeles Philharmonic Auditorium, of all places. Other records on the Internet refer to Hussane as Bulgarian or Turkish, and he is sometimes referred to by the nickname "The Terrible Turk." I can't find any references to him fighting anywhere other than the U.S., though. He was managed for a while by American sport promoter Jack Curley, according to Curley's Wikipedia biography.

comment.author: 30817808@N00
comment._content:
It was another, earlier Ottoman or Balkan wrestler,  Youssuf Ishmaelo, the Terrible Turk: the original (1) , in fact, of all the "Terrible Turks" who invaded western wrestling arenas over the past century,  this original via France.
Ismael Yousouf, known as the 'Terrible Turk'' to the wrestlers all over the world, was a steerage passenger on board La Bourgogne which sank in 1898. He was heading to Turkey/Ottoman Empire on the French transatlantic boat called La Bourgogne on May 21, 1898. But he couldn't end up in Istanbul and got drowned around the Sable Island (60 miles northeast to NY) due to a clash with an Irish cargo liner on July 4, 1898. His body was lost in the Atlantic Ocean.

He was born in Shumia, Turkey [now part of Bulgaria], thirty-five years ago. He was six feet two inches in height and weighted 240 pounds.Shortly after his victory over Lewis, Ismail took the first ship back to Europe where he reportedly planned to open a coffee or bazar in his native village of Scutari [in present day Albania].


THIS photographed GUY is another Yussif Hussane (2) who on either January 13, or January 15, 1917 he wrestled with Irishman Pat Connolly (who then himself went missing?) and they battled to a 2 1/2 hour draw in Butte, Montana, USA .

Later in Chicago IL: March 1, 1919: Hussane has been removed to the Garfield Boulevard Hospital here for treatment of an internal ailment that is puzzling the doctors. The wrestler was taken sick about 12 weeks ago and has had no relief since that time. He weighs but 159 pounds now where before he tipped the scales at 210. He has not appeared on the mat for the last four months and is under the care of Dr. B.W. Sippy. He was still wrestling until 1936.

comment.author: 10879063@N02
comment._content: After the La Bourgogne sank Youssuf Ishmaelo swam to a rescue boat and hang on to board. But it was full with other passengers and they afraid boat will sank because of  Youssuf. Some of the passenger hit his hands, arms but this strong man did not release his hands and then they started to hit him with oars but he still did not release his hands. Finally they hit his head and he sank into waters. This is the mournful death of  "Koca Yusuf" Youssuf Ishmaelo.

comment.author: 30817808@N00
comment._content: Gosh if that's true ("There has been told a tragic story about his drowning") that is a very sad ending for the man of strength (1) RIP. See him depicted on the right with two others in a memorial : www.flickr.com/photos/esteban08/2442383211/ en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koca_Yusuf

comment.author: 10879063@N02
comment._content:
This page will be a good resource :)
Last week I read from a book (Turkish"Önce Kadınlar ve Çocuklar" in English it means: Women and Children First  writer: Sunay AKIN a book about sinked ships in history) that a boat passenger cut his hand with an axe (which used to cut ropes of boat)  to get rid of him. 
Writer says that after accident his death body found in shores of Azores Islands. Also writer says that his grave is in the church's graveyard.
